Background and Analysis:
 
The District has six (6) pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment that the District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined are obsolete and of no further use to the District. In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
Purchasing Services will call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers. Proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The international student enrollment growth over the past ten years is due primarily to our increased international student recruitment efforts and to the intensive development  of formal relationships with private educational advising agencies around the world. These agents send students overseas to undertake their college and university study. Over the past seven years, we employed the services of this contractor, Gregory Barattini, who helped us to significantly increase the number of relationships we maintain with agents all over China, Indonesia, the rest of Southeast Asia and Europe. This expansion was a strong factor in past years in the District being able to increase international student enrollment  despite the very challenging economic environment. In addition, the contractor helped reduce the District's travel expenses by representing us at many international study abroad fairs and exhibitions.
	 
This contract would extend the services of Gregory Barattini for a one-year period starting July 1st. Mr. Barattini is a recognized professional expert and is one of few individuals known to the Foothill and De Anza International Programs Offices who provides this kind of international student recruitment representation to colleges and universities. For years, he worked as the senior vice president for marketing at several large international language school chains, recently represented Santa Monica College in a similar capacity over a four-year period, and has done an excellent job for FHDA over the past seven years. His clients also include Berkeley Colleges in New York City and UCLA Extension. He fully understands what the District has to offer and how to market us abroad, and is on a first-name  basis with a very large number of advising agents around the world. In addition, he is physically located in Indonesia, which allows him to travel inexpensively throughout the region and saves us considerable expenses.
	 
The contractor will provide year-round recruitment representation in Southeast and South Asia, in Turkey and in Scandinavia. Specifically, he will:
•     Develop relationships for FHDA with additional new educational  advising  agents;
•     Strengthen  relationships with existing agents;
•     Provide representation  at large study abroad fairs and agent seminars; and
•     Provide ongoing recruitment and international marketing advice.
	 
The contractor will provide these services to FHDA and to one or two other institutions, which will equally share in travel and related expenses. He will not represent any other community  college.
	 
The contractor will be paid $3,800.00 per month and will invoice us for the District's share of his travel expenses, which will not exceed $50,000.00 for the academic year.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner, Foothill College President
Additional contact names:
Kimberlee Messina
Is backup provided?
Yes

Background and Analysis:
	 
On March 12, 2015, the Associated Students of Foothill College (ASFC) Campus Council approved the budget for the fiscal year 2015-2016. 
	 
The goal of ASFC is to allocate funds intelligently and thoughtfully so that Foothill College students can receive quality services, support programs and engaging events. We hope that our efforts translate into the cultivation of a welcoming atmosphere and a positive learning environment.  The allocation of funds was discussed with these goals in mind.  Additionally, we were able to access and spend down a portion of our Fund Balance. 
	 
The manner in which ASFC provides funding to the campus community is based on our mission-based vision & goals, which are approved and adopted by members of ASFC every year. Our deliberation process began much earlier than previous years. We wanted to ensure that every decision we made was in accordance with our mission-based vision and goals, so we began our process in early Fall. This year, the budget development process went smoothly thanks to the collaborative work done by the budget team.

Background and Analysis:
	 
All public safety agencies (County and Municipal) in Santa Clara County have committed to move to the new interoperable radio system over the next few years.  A Joint Powers Authority (JPA) was created, Silicon Valley Regional Interoperable Authority (SVRIA), to oversee the project.  Similar JPA's exist in other Bay Area Counties and are all working together to help create what is envisioned as a Nationwide interoperable radio network (www.FirstNet.gov).
	 
Two agencies in Santa Clara County, Santa Clara and Sunnyvale, have already moved to the new system and other agencies are making plans to make the move in the future.  We currently have a contract with San Jose State University (SJSU) Police Department for dispatching services.  SJSU PD plans to transition to the new system in the first quarter of 2016.  To continue to make our dispatch services seamless, we will need to move to the new system at the same time that SJSU makes their transition.
	 
Recently, the Foothill-De Anza Board of Trustees approved District Purchasing to "piggyback" on the County's SVRIA contract for radio equipment, so we could purchase mobile and portable radios that are compatible with our existing radio infrastructure and the new SVRIA radio system.  That expenditure was approximately $120,000. This MOU is consistent for use of the equipment purchased.  
	 
The term of the MOU extends through the year 2029. The term length was necessary to pro rate the cost of the radio infrastructure, operations and maintenance over a period long enough to be affordable for all county agencies participating in the MOU. Foothill-De Anza's cost will be $21,378 annually for the first three years for infrastructure costs. Annual maintenance and operations costs will vary between $8,411 and $9,678 annually from FY 2018-19 through FY 2028-29.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Ronald Levine, Chief of Police

Background and Analysis:
	 
This project is to repaint the exterior facades and all painted components at the De Anza College Science Center Complex.
	 
ATI Architects and Engineers prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on March 13 and March 20, 2015. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to seven (7) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the San Jose Post Record as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on March 25, 2015, and a total of twelve (12) contractors attended the walk.  In accordance with the Instructions to Bidders, the award of the contract will be Pursuant to Public Contract Code Section 20103.8(a), the lowest bid shall be the lowest bid price on the base contract without consideration of the prices on the additive or deductive items. Bids were publicly opened and read on April 13, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office. Seven (7) contractors submitted bids and the bid results are summarized below:

Title:  Amendment #1 to the Preconstruction Services Agreement

Agreement Date:  February 10, 2015
Campus:  De Anza
Project Number:  202/275
Project Name:  L-7 Phase II
Amount:  $56,540
For: 
	 
Amendment #1 to the Preconstruction Services for the Phase 2 portion of the project. Swinerton will develop a Construction Schedule for bridging Phase 1 work with Phase 2, proceed with reviewing the Phase 2 design documentation for constructability, prequalify subcontractors for bidding, obtain competitive bids from subcontractors, and develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) for Phase 2 of the project. Swinerton’s fee for Revision #1 to the Preconstruction Services for Phase 2 is $46,540. The Preconstruction Services Agreement, paragraph VII(C), provides that the contractor will be reimbursed at actual cost for reimbursable services and is defined (in Phase 2) as providing Subcontractor’s engineered design support for the replacement of the raised floors and for the replacement of the Halon fire suppression system – both of which require design completion along with submission and approvals from the Division of the State Architect (DSA). Swinerton proposed and District staff agreed that Swinerton’s reimbursable services for this engineered design support effort is estimated at $7,500 but should not exceed $10,000. The total not-to-exceed cost for the Preconstruction Services Agreement was established at $56,540.
	 
It is intended that some of the necessary work of Phase 2 can be included in Phase 1 – utilizing the “Bridging Allowance” established in Phase 1 for this effort - with Swinerton’s assistance. Swinerton also will commence working with the Architect to complete the plans and Specifications for Phase 2 and then bid the work to generate an acceptable GMP for Phase 2. The District will then submit the GMP for Phase 2 to the Board for review, and if approved, Swinerton will sign amended Lease Agreements for Phase 2 work and will commence work based on the agreed-upon schedule. All of the remaining Phase 2 work is anticipated to start construction as early as late Summer 2015 immediately after Phase 1 has been completed to minimize costs and limit disruption of services in the L-7 vicinity. It is anticipated that Phase 2 will be completed by Spring 2016.

Background and Analysis:
	 
The Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement (Agreement) that is applicable to listed Measure C Bond Program projects was approved by the Board of Trustees at the April 7, 2008, meeting.
	 
The Agreement is between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Buildings & Construction Trades Council (Council) and affiliated and signatory local unions. Amendment No. 1 was submitted and approved by the Board of Trustees on May 7, 2012, that added specific Measure C projects to the list of projects covered by the Agreement.
	 
This Amendment No. 2 will add a local union - Asbestos, Lead and Mold Laborers Local 67 - as a signatory to the Agreement. At the time the Agreement was executed in 2008 and amended in 2012, the Asbestos, Lead and Mold Laborers Local 67 was not affiliated with the Council, a condition that has recently changed.  This Amendment No. 2 will have no noticeable effect on, or cost to, the District’s administration of the Agreement and is solely an administrative change.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, x6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, x6295, Tom Armstrong, x8289

Background and Analysis:
 
 
  
The roof system at Building 5600 on the Foothill College campus is approximately 12 years old and requires replacement.  The shakes are constructed with a mineral fiber imitation wood and are deteriorating. Furthermore, the warranty period has expired and the manufacturer of the product is no longer in business. This project requires the Contractor to remove the existing shake and built-up roof and replace in kind, including new flashing, underlayment, scuppers, sealants, and asphalt shingles.  An additive alternate was included for gutter improvements and a deductive aternate was also included as a cost savings measure to replace the specified 1 ¼” jumbo wood shakes with a ¾” wood shake.  The project will begin this summer and it is anticipated to be complete by early fall.  Allana Buick & Bers Architects prepared the bid specifications for the project.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on March 25 and March 31, 2015. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to several local builder’s exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and was posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com. Bids were publicly opened and read on April 16, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office. Seven (7) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:

Background and Analysis:
	 
The Campus Center exterior and the pedestrian bridge at Foothill College are weathering and are in poor condition.  For this project, the Contractor will prepare the surfaces for new paint or stain where indicated, protect the area, remove all debris and wastewater in accordance with the District’s policies and procedures, repaint and stain the surfaces.   Alternate scopes of work include staining of the existing wood louver screen, reducing the amount of preparation work on the Campus Center buildings and the bridge by providing different cleaning methodologies, and professionally washing the Campus Center windows at the completion of the project.  The project will begin this summer and it is anticipated to be complete by early fall.  Prodis Associates Architects prepared the bid specifications for the project.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on March 3 and March 10, 2015. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to several local builder’s exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and was posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory job walk was held beginning at 10:30 am on March 17, 2015. Bids were publicly opened and read on April 14, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office. Three (3) contractors submitted bids. Bid results are below:

The determination of the lowest responsive, responsible bidder is pursuant to Public Contract Code section 20103.8(a) which states “the lowest bid shall be the lowest total of the bid price on the base contract without consideration of alternates.”  Therefor the apparent low responsive, responsible bidder is Industrial Coating & Restoration Services, Inc. (Industrial Coating).  
	 
The District received a bid protest from OnPoint Construction on April 16, 2015 citing that Industrial Coating did not comply with the “minimum requirements of the Districts Mandatory Walk through criteria” because Industrial Coating arrived when the Mandatory Walk Through was effectively over and the group was departing.  The District acknowledges that a representative from Industrial Coating did arrive approximately 45 minutes into the job walk near its conclusion. 
	 
The Notice to Contractors states “the District will conduct a mandatory Job-Walk for all contractors for the Work.  The Job-Walk will be conducted beginning at 10:30 a.m. on 3/17/2015” and the Instructions for Bidders states that “the failure of any Bidder to have its authorized representative present at the Mandatory Job-Walk will render the Bid Proposal of such Bidder to be non-responsive.”  Industrial Coating did have an authorized representative at the Job walk. Therefore, it met the minimum requirement stated by the District.  Purchasing staff also consulted with the District’s legal representative, Mr. Phillip Jaret of Jaret & Jaret Attorneys at Law.  It is the opinion of Mr. Jaret that the bid submitted by Industrial Coating is legally compliant and the contractor fulfilled the Mandatory Walk Through Criteria in Document 00 21 13 – Instructions to Bidders.  
	 
Industrial Coating has confirmed that its bid price of $135,000 is true and accurate for the work as specified. Alternates #1 and #4 will not be accepted at this time; however, if the campus identifies additional funding for such work, then the bid specifications provide that the alternate can be accepted at a later date at the same cost provided in the bid proposal.  Industrial Coating has also performed work for Inland Empire Utilities, U.S. Forestry, and Lake Casitas Water District. 
	 
The bid price of $135,000 will be paid for with Campus Center funds and also Measure C funds.  Alternates #1 and #4 will not be accepted at this time; however, if the campus identifies additional funding for such work, then the bid specifications provide that the alternate can be accepted at a later date at the same cost provided in the bid proposal.
